justification: The article notes that “adults who respond more quickly to trivia questions are also rated as more charismatic by peers (von Hippel et al., 2016),” indicating that peer ratings are the instrument used to measure the construct of charisma.

It states that “adults interpret longer latencies as reluctance in response to requests (Roberts, Francis, & Morgan, 2006),” showing that the length of response time is treated as the measure of reluctance.

The text reports that longer answer times are understood “as memory failure in response to trivia questions (Brennan & Williams, 1995),” linking the construct of memory failure to the duration of response time.

The article says adults view longer latencies “as indecision between equally desirable options in decision-making (Frydman & Krajbich, 2016; Gates et al., 2021),” identifying response time as the measure of indecision.
It notes that “buyers' hesitation (or lack thereof) can reveal their price-point… (Konovalov & Krajbich, 2017),” indicating that the construct ‘price-point’ is inferred from the amount of hesitation.
